overview.short: Methylobacterium species are Gram-negative, aerobic, pink-pigmented rods capable of utilizing methanol as a sole carbon source.
overview.clinical_context: Primarily environmental organisms; occasionally isolated from hospital water systems and immunocompromised patients, often as opportunistic contaminants.

field_notes.Pigment: Colonies produce a characteristic pink coloration due to carotenoid pigments.
field_notes.Glucose Fermentation: Non-fermentative metabolism; growth on methanol distinguishes the genus.

key_differentiators.notes: Pink pigment and methanol utilization distinguish Methylobacterium.
Urease activity is common among Methylobacterium but not other non-fermenters.
Oxidase positivity helps narrow within pink-pigmented non-fermenters.

common_confusions.reason: Both are pink-pigmented, oxidase-positive rods; Roseomonas often shows coccoid shape and poor growth on minimal media.
Some Acinetobacter species may appear slightly pigmented, but are oxidase-negative.

when_to_question_identification: Absence of pink pigmentation suggests a different non-fermenter.
Oxidase-negative isolate is inconsistent with Methylobacterium.
Fermentative glucose reaction excludes this genus.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Confirms methylotrophic metabolism characteristic of Methylobacterium.
Supports placement among oxidase-positive aerobic rods.
